questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator that can be used in chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction?
questions.solution:
Vericiguat is an oral soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator that can be used in the treatment of chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
 
By stimulating guanylate cyclase, it enhances the production of cGMP which leads to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilatation. It also enhances the sensitivity of soluble guanylate cyclase to endogenous NO which further contributes to increased cGMP. 
 
It reduces the risk of cardiovascular death following hospitalization for heart failure in symptomatic chronic heart failure and ejection fraction <45%.
 
Other options:
 
Option A: Riociguat is also a soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator but it is used in pulmonary artery hypertension and not in heart failure.
 
Option C: Omapatrilat is a neprilysin and ACE inhibitor developed for heart failure that is not used due to the side effect of increased levels of bradykinin. 
 
Option D: Treprostinil is a prostacyclin analog that acts as a vasodilator used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:
 
Intravenous vasodilators

Nitroglycerine

Sodium nitroprusside

 Decrease preload and afterload
Nesiritide Recombinant human BNP
 
Intravenous positive inotropes

Dobutamine

Dopamine

Epinephrine

Norepinephrine

 β1 receptor-mediated stimulation of cardiac output

Enoximone

Milrinone

 PDE 3/4 inhibitors

Levosimendan

Pimobendan

 Combined Ca2+ sensitizers and PDE3 inhibitors
 
Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

 Loop diuretics- used for symptomatic treatment of severe heart failure and acute decompensation.
Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:
Drugs Uses
ACE inhibitors Used as first-line therapy
ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors
Beta-blockers Used as first-line therapy  

Spironolactone

Eplerenone

 Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists - first-line drugs for symptomatic heart failure.
SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity
Sacubitril/Valsartan Neprilysin inhibitor/ARB(ARNI)
Ivabradine Inhibitor of If current in the sinoatrial node

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented to your clinic with complaints of painful skin eruptions for the past 4 days. They are present on his face, over his wrists, and on the anterior surface of both arms. He also has a fever since yesterday. On examination, pulse rate is 97 beats per minute, BP is 100/70 mm of Hg, and the temperature is 99.8F. The skin eruptions include macules, vesicles, pustules, and crusted lesions. The skin surrounding the lesions is erythematous. There is submandibular and cervical lymphadenopathy. An image of the rash on the face is shown below. On enquiring, the mother says that he has had several episodes of itchy rashes over the last 5 years that are currently seen as dry, scaly, lichenified patches on the flexural surfaces and back. What is the most likely diagnosis of the newly formed rash?
questions.solution:
In the above case, recurrent itchy, lichenified rashes on the flexural surfaces suggest atopic dermatitis. The most probable diagnosis of the new painful eruptions in the setting of preexisting atopic dermatitis is Kaposi varicelliform eruption or eczema herpeticum.

Kaposi Varicelliform eruption or Eczema herpeticum refers to widespread cutaneous infection with a virus that normally causes localized or mild vesicular eruptions, occurring in a patient with pre‐existing skin disease. 

The usual causative virus is HSV‐1. Other viruses that may cause Kaposi varicelliform eruption include HSV-2, VZV, and Coxsackie A.

The commonest predisposing condition is atopic dermatitis, whereas Darier disease and Pemphigus foliaceous are less common predisposing conditions.

Clinical presentation of Kaposi varicelliform eruption includes-

  • Lesions that may be localized or widespread
  • Vesicles that erupt in massive crops for 5 to 7 days 
  • Vesicles that rapidly become pustular or sometimes hemorrhagic. They rupture leaving small superficial erosions which may then weep and crust
  • Skin that is painful and erythematous
  • Regional lymph nodes that may be enlarged
  • High fever that commonly develops 2 or 3 days after the onset of the eruption.

Localized Kaposi varicelliform eruption may be self-resolving or may be treated with oral acyclovir. Patients with a widespread disease may need treatment with IV acyclovir.  

Other options-

Option A- Atopic dermatitis is a recurrent inflammatory skin disorder. In children, it is characterized by dry, scaly, pruritic, excoriated, or lichenified papules, and plaques in flexural areas, back, and neck. This patient's past history is suggestive of atopic dermatitis. However, the newer skin eruption is more characteristic of Kaposi varicelliform eruption. 

Option B- Herpes Zoster or Shingles is a viral infection caused due to the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus. It typically causes burning, painful vesicles that are usually confined to a single dermatome on one side of the body. 

Option C- Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with Celiac disease. It includes intensely pruritic inflammatory papules and vesicles on the forearms, knees, scalp, or buttocks.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought with severe pain in his right thigh which has worsened over the last few months. He also has frequent nose bleeds and gets fatigued easily while playing. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leukocyte assay with low levels of beta-glucosidase activity. What is the inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of bone pain, epistaxis, hepatosplenomegaly, and low levels of β-glucosidase suggests a diagnosis of Gaucher's disease that is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Gaucher's disease is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of the enzyme acid β-glucosidase. This leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the cells of the reticuloendothelial system.

The clinical features result from the accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, bone, and other tissues. It is characterized by hematologic abnormalities, organomegaly, and skeletal involvement like bone pain and pathological fractures. There are 3 clinical subtypes :

Type 1 - presents from early childhood to late adulthood. These patients present with:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Bone pain
  • Pathological fractures
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Chronic fatigue
  • Erlenmeyer flask deformity of distal femur

Type 2 - acute neuronopathic form. These patients have a rapid neurodegenerative course and present with increased tone, strabismus, and organomegaly. These patients die within 1 year of life.

Type 3 - juvenile or subacute neuronopathic form. It presents in childhood and there is death by 10-15 years of age.

Gaucher cells are the pathological hallmark of the disease. They are seen in the reticuloendothelial system, especially in the bone marrow. It has a wrinkled paper appearance due to the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions. The cytoplasm of the Gaucher cell is strongly PAS-positive.

Gaucher's disease is treated with enzyme replacement therapy.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

S. No.

Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Lipid

Accumulating

Clinical Symptoms

1

Tay–Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A

Ganglioside

Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness

2

Sandhoff's disease

Hexosaminidase A and B

Globoside & Ganglioside

Similar to Tay–Sachs disease but also has hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal dysplasias

3

Fabry's disease

α-Galactosidase

Globotriaosyl-ceramide

Skin rash, kidney failure (full symptoms only in males; X-linked recessive)

4

Metachromatic leukodystrophy

Arylsulfatase A

3-Sulfogalactosyl-ceramide

Mental retardation and psychologic disturbances in adults; demyelination

5

β-Galactosidase

Mental retardation; myelin almost absent

6

β-Glucosidase

7

questions.text: A 45-year-old motorcycle rider was brought 7 hours after sustaining the following injury in an RTA. On examination, the pulse rate is 120bpm, blood pressure is  80/60mmHg. Distal pulses were not palpable, the limb was cold on touch and paralyzed. The patient couldn't move any of the distal toes. X-ray of the left leg showed a comminuted fracture of the tibia and fibula. As an orthopedic resident on casualty duty, you classify the injury as ____ as per the Gustilo Anderson classification and post it for OT. The consultant surgeon performs a ________. Select the correct set of options.

choices.text: Type2, debridement and internal fixation and immediate closure

questions.solution:
The clinical image shows an open fracture with a wound with extensive soft tissue loss and periosteal stripping and bone damage belongs to classification III. 

The decision to salvage the limb or go for amputation is decided upon by various scores which predict the outcome based on the viability of the limb. Mangled extremity severity score is one such score.

A score of 6 or less is consistent with the salvageable limb. A reconstruction after surgical debridement is a better option here.

A score of 7 or more is consistent with the limb eventually resulting in amputation.

Mangled Extremity severity score calculated for this patient is calculated as below:

  • Age -45 years (30-50 years) - 1 point
  • Shock - Hypotensive - 1 point at least (since the response to fluids is not mentioned)
  • Limb ischemia - Cold, pulseless, paralyzed limb - 3*2 points - 6 points
  • Skeletal - medium energy injury - multiple fractures -2 points 

This totals to about - 10 points. Since it is more than 7, amputation would be a likely option.

Related Pearl: Gustilo and Anderson classification for open fracture

Gustilo-Anderson's classification for open injuries    
Type Wound Level of contamination Soft tissue injury Bone injury
I <1 cm Clean Minimal Simple, minimal comminution
II >1 cm Moderate Moderate; some muscle damage Moderate comminution
IIIA usually >10 cm High Severe with crushing Usually comminuted; soft tissue coverage of bone possible
IIIB usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery
IIIC usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover; vascular injury requiring repair Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery


Management according to Gustilo-Anderson's classification:

Types Methods of fixation
Grade  I                                A technique that is suitable for closed fracture management i.e, debridement and internal fixation by intramedullary nail and plate  
Grade II, IIIA

Within 6hr same as grade I and after 6hr same as IIIB, IIIC
Grade IIIB, IIIC

Debridement and external fixation

Related Pearl: Mangled Extremity Severity Score

1 Low energy  Stab wounds, simple closed fractures small-callber gunshot wounds 1
2 Medium energy Open or multiple-level fractures, dissociations, moderate crush injuries 2
3 High energy Shotgun blast (close range), high-velocity wounds 3

SHOCK GROUP

MESS score of < 7 is usually associated with salvageable limb.

MESS score of ≥ 7 is usually associated with the requirement of limb amputation.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old baby is brought to you during your rural posting. The child had loose stools for the past 10 days. On examination, there is no fever or associated blood or mucus in stools. Her pulse is 160 bpm and her respiratory rate is 30 per minute. The child doesn't react to your comments and seems lethargic. The skin remains tented after pinching. You ask the mother to make her drink water but the child doesn't readily drink. Which of the following measures would you consider to manage this patient?
  1. Offer Low osmolarity ORS solution
  2. Give Zinc supplementation 
  3. Start her on IV fluids 
  4. Give her empiric antibiotics
questions.solution:
The child in this scenario has severe dehydration since the child is lethargic, hardly drinks water,  and the skin goes back very slowly on the skin pinch test and remains tented. Among the given options-1,2,3 should be given

She needs to be treated according to WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) Protocol, Plan C. It includes

  • IV fluid therapy at 30ml/kg over ½ hour followed by 70ml/kg over 2 ½ hours. If dehydration persists, continue IV fluids.
  • If dehydration improves, low osmolarity Oral rehydration fluid to be given when she accepts oral feeds, and
  • Zinc supplementation 20mg/d given for 14 days.

Note: Children who can drink, even poorly, should be given ORS solution by mouth until the IV drip is running.
If IV therapy is not available nearby, health workers who have been trained can give ORS solution by NG tube, at a rate of 20 ml/kg body weight per hour for six hours (total of 120 ml/kg body weight)

Antimicrobials are not needed in acute diarrhoea (<14 days) unless it is due to amebiasis, giardiasis, cholera, and dysentery. 

Diarrhoea may be a manifestation of systemic infection or sepsis. It may be suspected in the presence of poor sucking, abdominal distension, fever or hypothermia, fast breathing, significant lethargy or inactivity in well-nourished, well-hydrated infants. In the presence of these, age-appropriate systemic antibiotics may be given.

Approach to diarrhoea as per IMNCI PLANS:

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Mrs. Rao, a 50-year-old woman with a 10-day history of nasal discharge, headache that increases on bending down, and pain over the medial canthus, now presents to the outpatient department with high-grade fever and chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On further inquiry, it is brought to light that the proptosis began in the right eye, and since yesterday, the left eye has also been affected. On examination, her pulse rate is 56 beats per minute, BP is 150/96 mm of Hg, the temperature is 102F.  There is periorbital edema, proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia. The pupillary response is sluggish. Fundoscopy reveals papilloedema.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with recurrent episodes of headache and pain over the medial canthus and repeated use of nasal decongestants, suggests that the patient was suffering from sinusitis which has most likely resulted in cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a septic thrombus formed in the cavernous sinus. It spreads from infection of the sinuses, teeth, ears, nose, and skin of the face. The contents of the cavernous venous sinus that may be affected include

  • Cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery
  • Perivascular sympathetic plexus
  • Abducens nerve (running through the Dorello’s canal)
  • Oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve as part of the lateral wall. 

It presents as fever, severe headache, supraorbital pain, seizures, and edema in the mastoid region. Eye signs include proptosis, chemosis, and diplopia due to ophthalmoplegia from the involvement of oculomotor (CN-III), trochlear (CN-IV), and abducens nerve (CN-VI). Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (CN-Va). Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex due to oculomotor nerve palsy. Pulsatile proptosis occurs with the involvement of the internal carotid artery.

Clinically, the feature that strongly suggests the diagnosis is the pattern and bilaterality of the proptosis. In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through intercavernous communication. 

Investigation using brain MRI or MR venography should be done urgently. Following early diagnosis, management of cavernous sinus thrombosis typically includes IV broad-spectrum antibiotics and anticoagulants. 

Other options :

Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, squint, and defective vision.

Option B- Orbital pseudotumor also called idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, and conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

questions.text: Mr. Roy comes with pain, itching, and scant, foul-smelling discharge in his left ear after a vacation in Goa. On examination, the ear canal appears oedematous and inflamed, the tympanic membrane is normal, and there is pain when the auricle is pulled upward. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of acute otitis externa and the most appropriate management among the given options is prescribing a topical antibiotic solution.

Otitis externa is the inflammation of the external auditory canal. It is also called the swimmer's ear. The pathogenesis primarily involves the disruption of the skin-cerumen barrier. The factors that may contribute to this include heat and humidity seen during warmer months, maceration of the skin of the ear canal as seen during swimming (which is the likely cause in this patient), alkaline pH, and trauma to the ear canal. 

Examination findings of purulent discharge with the debris, as in this case, are suggestive of a bacterial etiology. The most common bacteriae responsible are Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Staphylococcus aureus.

Clinically, otitis externa can be classified into the following based on severity-

  • Mild disease- characterized by minor discomfort and pruritus. There is minimal canal edema.

  • Moderate disease- characterized by an intermediate degree of pain and pruritus. There is partial canal occlusion. 

  • Severe disease- characterized by fever, periauricular erythema, lymphadenopathy, and intense pain. There is complete canal occlusion due to edema. 

Treatment-

  • Mild to moderate cases are treated using topical solutions containing
    • Antibiotics such as ofloxacin, ciprofloxacin, polymyxin B, or neomycin
    • Acidifying agents
    • Corticosteroids.
  • Severe otitis externa is managed with systemic antibiotics or wick placement. 

This patient with pruritis, mild pain, and partial canal occlusion due to edema has moderate otitis externa. Therefore, antibiotic drops after aural toilet by dry mopping, suction clearance, or irrigating the canal with warm, sterile normal saline are the most appropriate course of management. 

Other options-

Options A and B- Surgical debridement along with systemic antibiotics may be required in malignant otitis externa. It is a severe, fatal complication of acute bacterial otitis externa which is seen in elderly diabetics and immunocompromised individuals. It occurs when the infection spreads to the surrounding soft tissue, cartilage, and skull bones. On examination, the skin of the ear canal appears completely necrotic and granulation tissue is classically seen at the bony-cartilaginous junction of the external canal. 

Option D- Nystatin ear ointment or other topical antifungals are used in the management of otomycosis. Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external canal. It is unlikely in this case because otomycosis has characteristic findings such as black spots, or soft white material in the ear canal. It can occur secondarily to a bacterial otitis externa treated with antibiotics.

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with a history of acute onset of anxiety and hyperactivity. His friend gives a history of substance abuse. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, high blood pressure and dilated pupils were noted. The toxicity of which of the following drugs can be suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario patient presenting with anxiety, hyperactivity, tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis with a history of substance abuse points towards a diagnosis of cocaine toxicity leading to sympathetic toxidrome.

Cocaine is a CNS stimulant obtained from coca plants belonging to the family Erythroxylaceae. It is also known as Coke, snow and white lady. The route of intake is by snorting, IV route and smoking. Tattoos may be made to cover the injection marks.

It inhibits the uptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.

At lower doses, it leads to alertness but at higher doses, it produces stereotyped behavior, involuntary actions, and paranoia. There is a transient euphoria. Tactile hallucinations (Magnan's symptom or cocaine bugs) are characteristic. 

There is a dose-dependent increase in heart rate and blood pressure. It causes dilation of pupils and is associated with chills and perspiration. In severe cases, intracranial bleeding due to increased blood pressure, and myocardial infarction due to coronary vasospasm can occur. Ultimately, the patient goes into a stage of depression with loss of reflexes, paralysis of muscles, cardiorespiratory failure, and coma.  

Management -  Administration of activated charcoal and gastric lavage with warm water and potassium permanganate in case of ingestion. Benzodiazepines to control heart rate/seizures. Amyl nitrite is the antidote given via inhalation. Thiamine 100 mg IV and Naloxone 2 mg IV can also be given.

Other options:

Option A - Benzodiazepines is a CNS depressant. They would present with dizziness, diplopia, dysarthria, ataxia and drowsiness. In overdose, respiratory depression and hypotension may occur, unlike the CNS stimulant effects of cocaine.

Option B - Cannabis acts on THC (tetrahydrocannabinol) receptors. It causes euphoria followed by narcosis. There is inattention, motor incoordination, ataxia, tremors, conjunctival suffusion, and somnolence, unlike cocaine which causes hyperactivity.

Option C - Heroin (opium) presents with an initial excitement followed by giddiness and headache. There is a fall in BP, heart rate, respiratory rate in the later stages and pupils are constricted.  

The image below shows the Erythroxylum plant:

Related Pearl: Common names of Drugs of abuse

Drug of abuse Common name
Cocaine White lady, Coke, Blow, Snow
Cannabis Weed, Pot, Reefer, Ganja, Mary Jane, Hash, Indian hemp
Heroin Smack, Dope, Brown sugar, Snowball
Ketamine Vitamin K, Special K, Super K
LSD Acid
Methamphetamine Ice, Meth, Crystal,
MDMA Ecstasy
Phencyclidine Angel dust

 

Forms of cannabis:

Bhang: Decoction prepared from dried leaves and fruit shoot

Majoon: Sweet prepared from bhang

Ganja: Prepared from flower tops of female plant and smoked

Hashish/Charas: Most potent; resin exudate from leaves and stem that's smoked

questions.text: Rama, a 40-year-old female patient came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the lower limb as shown below. The swelling is more on the distal aspect than proximal and is more at the end of the day. On examination, there is non-pitting edema associated with the thickening of the skin. She says that her place has a lot of people with similar deformities. Which of the following is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: It is caused due to obstruction of lymphatics by adult worms of Wuchereria bancrofti
Culex  mosquito transmits the Wuchereria microfilaria which grow into adults in human
Diagnosis can be done by antigen detection using card test and microscopic detection of microfilaria using night-time sample
A combination of Ivermectin, DEC and Albendazole is recommended for mass prophylaxis and transmission interruption

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis. It occurs due to the transmission of stage III filariform larva (not microfilaria) by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. 

The disease initially causes acute attacks of lymphangitis and lymphadenitis. Early treatment may even cure the disease.

As time goes by the lymphedema worsens and is associated with thickening of the skin and fibrosis of lymph vessels or blockage by adult worms. Management during the later phase involves the prevention of local infection and disability limitation.

High yield points to remember:

  • W.bancrofti causes Bancroftian filariasis and is transmitted by C. quinquefasciatus (C. fatigans). In India, Wuchereria bancrofti is the commonest cause of filariasis.
  • B. malayi causes Burgian filariasis and the vector is Mansonia mosquito
  • It occurs due to transmission of filariform larva (stage III larva), whereas, the microfilaria is the larval stage that circulates in the human blood, which is ingested by mosquito during the blood meal.
  • The extrinsic incubation period (duration of the mosquito cycle) is 10-14 days under optimal humidity and temperature
  • The reservoir of infection: humans (predominantly in India) and animals· 

Diagnosis:

  • Mass blood survey to detect microfilaria in 5-7% of the total population – done at night time – 10 pm to 4 am (maximum parasite activity at this time)
  • The membrane filter concentration (MFC) method is the most sensitive technique, but very-low-density Mf carriers will not be detected· 

Management:

  • Use of TDT - Ivermectin + Diethylcarbamazine citrate (DEC) + albendazole  
  • Mass drug administration is done in endemic areas with more than 80% coverage and done for 5-6 years on annual basis. The MDA is done using DEC+ Albendazole or Albendazole + Ivermectin· 

Indicators for lymphatic filariasis under NVBDCP:

  • Filarial endemicity rate: Proportion of population showing either microfilaria in blood or symptoms of filariasis or both  
  • Microfilaria density: Number of microfilaria/unit volume of blood (20 mm3)

India accounts for up to 40% of the world's filariasis cases. The majority are transmitted by Wuchereria bancrofti (commoner than Brugya malayi). Dedicated efforts have been put by governments to control and eliminate filariasis by mass drug administration of DEC and albendazole for 5 years. It is followed by a transmission assessment survey (TAS) which tests for the presence of filarial antigens in the blood.

Recently, accelerated efforts have been put towards the elimination of filariasis. A Triple drug combination of IDA( Ivermectin, DEC, and Albendazole) has been introduced as a faster and effective alternative. A mini-TAS survey is conducted on school-going children.

questions.text: A young man who had severe anemia underwent a blood transfusion with packed red blood cells. One hour later he appeared pale and developed fever with chills, flank pain, and dark-colored urine. A direct Coombs test was positive. Which of the following is implicated in this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Type II hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in this patient presenting with acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) following blood transfusion. It occurs most often due to ABO incompatibility and commonly occurs due to negligence in patient identification or tube labeling.

Type II hypersensitivity reaction is antibody-mediated. In ABO incompatibility, preformed IgM antibodies attack the antigens on donor red cells which causes complement fixation. This results in complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria. Complement activation produces fever with shaking chills. The patient appears pale due to hemolysis and has acute flank pain with dark-colored urine (hemoglobinuria).

The direct Coombs test is usually positive. Direct Coombs test/antiglobulin test is done on the surface of red blood cells. The Coombs reagent consists of anti-human antibodies. On combining with the red blood cells, the test becomes positive, if there are RBC antibodies present in the sample. This is because the anti-human antibodies in the reagent bind with the human antibodies in the RBCs and form a link. 

Other options:

Option A: Type I hypersensitivity reaction is IgE mediated. An anaphylactic blood transfusion reaction is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. However, it presents within seconds to minutes of blood transfusion with hypotension, urticaria, angioedema, and wheezing.

Option C: Type III hypersensitivity reaction, also known as immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, occurs when antigen-antibody complexes deposition leads to complement activation. Examples include SLE, serum sickness, and the Arthus reaction.

Option D: Type IV hypersensitivity , also known as a cell-mediated or delayed hypersensitivity reaction, is caused by activated T lymphocytes. Examples include contact dermatitis and tuberculin skin testing.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with low backache for three months. On examination, his ankle and knee jerk reflexes were absent. But, pain and temperature sensations were preserved. MRI shows lumbar disc prolapse at L3-L4. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of cauda equina syndrome secondary to a lumbar disc prolapse.

Compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots below the level of termination of the spinal cord that is L1-L2 results in cauda-equina syndrome (CES). Common causes of CES include ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disc, epidural hematoma, vertebral fracture, and compressive tumor. 

Patients with CES usually present with low back pain, asymmetrical weakness, variable areflexia, diminished sensation in the buttocks and posterosuperior thighs, and perineal region. Absent bulbocavernosus, patellar (knee), and Achilles (ankle) reflexes are characteristically seen in CES.

MRI of the entire spine must be done promptly.

Management includes starting dexamethasone immediately, radiation therapy plus glucocorticoids in case of spinal cord compression, and surgical decompression by laminectomy or diskectomy for disc rupture.

Other options:

Option A: Central cord syndrome results due to damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the spinothalamic tract crossing the central canal. Patients present with features are loss of pain and temperature sensation which are not seen in this patient.

Option B: Conus medullaris syndrome is characterized by bilateral saddle anesthesia, and prominent bowel and bladder dysfunction. Also, anal and bulbocavernosus reflexes are absent. 

Option D: Brown-Sequard syndrome is a hemi-transection of the spinal cord. It presents with ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract), ipsilateral loss of position, vibration sense (posterior column), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature one or two levels below the lesion.

Related Pearl: Conus medullaris syndrome vs Cauda equina syndrome

 

Conus medullaris syndrome

Cauda equina syndrome
Injury

Vertebral column injuries between T12 and L2

 Vertebral column injuries distal to L2
Pathophysiology

Upper and lower motor neuron involvement

 Lower motor neuron involvement
Motor strength 

Symmetrical motor impairment 

 Asymmetrical motor impairment
Reflexes Knee jerk preserved, ankle jerk affected Both knee and ankle jerk affected
Sphincter dysfunction Urinary retention presents early in the disease course Urinary retention presents late in the disease course
 

Absent bulbocavernosus reflex
 

Radicular pain and low back pain

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is being evaluated for decreased urine output. One week ago, he was admitted to the intensive care unit with pneumonia. He was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including a third-generation cephalosporin and gentamicin. His vitals are now stable. The results of laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following types of casts would you find in this patient?

Hb%- 12 g/dL

WBC: 12,000 cells/μL;

         Neutrophils - 50%

         Lymphocytes- 40%

         Eosinophils- 2%

         Monocytes- 7%

         Basophils- 1%

Platelets : 200,000/μL

Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 40 mg/dL

Serum creatinine: 3.8 mg/dL

Serum Na+: 133 mEq/L

Serum K+: 5.8 mEq/L

Serum Cl-: 108 mEq/L

Urinary protein: <1g/dL

FeNa: 2.2%
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of oliguria with increased serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is suggestive of acute kidney injury (AKI), probably following the use of gentamicin, a nephrotoxic drug. Muddy brown granular casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis, which is a type of intrinsic renal failure. Tubular epithelial casts can also be seen in acute tubular necrosis.

In this patient,

  • BUN/Creatinine ratio is 40/3.8 = 10.5:1 which is <15:1, and
  • Fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) is >1% 

Both these parameters are suggestive of intrinsic acute kidney injury.

Common causes of intrinsic AKI:

  • Acute glomerulonephritis
  • Tubulointerstitial diseases
  • Vasculitis
  • Hemolytic-uremic syndrome
  • Malignant hypertension

Tubulointerstitial diseases are caused due to ischemia, sepsis/infection, or nephrotoxins. Nephrotoxins can be exogenous or endogenous.

  • Exogenous nephrotoxins: Aminoglycosides, cisplatin, amphotericin-B, acyclovir, vancomycin, zoledronate, iodinated contrast
  • Endogenous nephrotoxins: Products of hemolysis, rhabdomyolysis, myeloma proteins

Laboratory findings in AKI due to acute tubular necrosis:

  • Acute kidney injury is associated with anemia, which is multifactorial in origin. Uremia leads to a reduction in platelet function, although the platelet count remains normal, thereby causing bleeding and leading to anemia.
  • AKI is typically associated with hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.
  • Damage to the tubular cells and interstitium leads to decreased reabsorption of Na+, which results in fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) of >1%. This patient has hyponatremia due to increased urinary Na+ excretion. 

Other options:

Option A: Hyaline casts are seen in patients with prerenal acute kidney injury. In prerenal AKI, BUN/Creatinine ratio is >20. Common conditions associated with prerenal AKI include hypovolemia; congestive heart failure; liver failure; and impaired renal autoregulation due to drugs like NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).

Option C: RBC casts are seen in acute glomerulonephritis. This patient does not have hypertension or proteinuria to signify glomerular pathology.

Option D: WBC casts are seen in patients with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). A patient with AIN presents with fever, flank pain, rash, and arthralgia. Urinalysis shows sterile pyuria. CBC shows eosinophilia (not seen in this patient).

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A young man presents to an emergency room with sudden onset of the chest and epigastric pain. An ECG done reveals no abnormality. On palpation, you hear a crunchy sound of the chest and rigidity in the epigastric region. An X-ray chest of the patient is given below. Which among the following contrasts is contraindicated in confirming the diagnosis using fluoroscopy?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with crunchy sound on chest palpation and an x-ray showing pneumothorax (white arrow) and pleural effusion (black arrowhead) in the chest points towards a diagnosis of esophageal perforation. Water-insoluble contrast media like barium sulphate is contraindicated to confirm the diagnosis using fluoroscopy. 

Esophageal perforation most commonly occurs due to iatrogenic instrumentation. Spontaneous perforation occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis—Boerhaave syndrome. Clinically, patients typically will have pain in the chest and epigastric region. On examination, abdominal rigidity and a crunchy sound on chest palpation (Hamman's sign) due to subcutaneous emphysema from leakage of air into subcutaneous space are seen. 

The classic chest radiographic findings include pneumomediastinum, left pleural effusion, and left pneumothorax.

Low-osmolar water-soluble contrast medium like iopamidol is used for the diagnostic workup for a suspected case of esophageal perforation instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum. However, if water-soluble contrast media is not available, diluted barium can be used.

Barium sulfate is not normally absorbed during its passage through the digestive tract. However when the integrity of the gut wall is compromised or when there is abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea, it can overflow into the lungs, mediastinum, intraperitoneal cavity, and tissue around the rectum and cause inflammation. Hence, it is contraindicated in these cases.

Contraindications to use of barium:

  • Esophageal perforation: Iodinated contrast media like iopamidol and iohexol are used; gastrograffin can also be used but is not preferred due to risk of aspiration pneumonitis.
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula: dianosil, the water-soluble non-ionic agent is used.
  • Duodenal perforation: iohexol or gastrograffin is used.

The image given below shows contrast esophagogram showing leakage of dye through the leak/perforation site:

 

The image given below shows an axial CT thorax showing extraluminal air surrounding the esophagus and trachea:

Related Pearl: Classification of iodinated contrast medias:

  Iodinated contrast materials  
Types Ionic  Non-ionic
Subtypes  Monomer Dimer Monomer Dimer
Osmolarity

1400- 1600 mOsm (Not preferred due to high osmolarity)

 600- 800 mOsm 600- 800 mOsm 300 mOsm
Iodine: particle ratio 3:2 6:2 or 3:1 3:1 6:1
Examples 

Diatrizoate (Urograffin)

Iothalamate

Ioxaglate

Iohexol (most commonly used)

Ioversol

Iopamidol

Iodixanol

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, G2P1L1 comes for her first ANC visit at 10 weeks gestation. Her previous pregnancy was uneventful with a normal vaginal delivery six years ago. The patient is a known hypertensive for 3 years but is non-compliant with her medications and has not had regular follow up. She occasionally smokes but does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. On examination, her pulse rate is 80 bpm and BP is 150/90 mm of Hg. You prescribe multivitamins and advise her regarding the need for blood pressure control. This patient is at an increased risk of developing ___.
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic hypertension is at increased risk of developing abruptio placentae. It is the premature separation of a normally implanted placenta.

The hemorrhage into decidua basalis causes separation and compression of the placenta. This leads to a compromise of circulation to the fetus leading to fetal distress. The bleeding may escape through the cervix to cause external hemorrhage.

Hypertension and smoking are important etiological factors in abruption. Hypertension leads to vasospasm of the placental blood vessels, which causes uteroplacental insufficiency. 

Placental insufficiency and damage to the vessels cause bleeding from the placental tissue and its separation from the uterine decidua. The fetus is also at risk of intrauterine growth restriction.

The other common etiological factors for abruptio placentae include:

  • Preterm prematurely ruptured membranes
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Cocaine abuse
  • Trauma
  • Uterine fibroids
  • Isolated single umbilical artery
  • Short umbilical cord
  • Prior abruption
  • Subclinical hypothyroidism

Other options:

Option B: Placenta previa is the implantation of the placenta in the lower uterine segment, either over or very near to the cervical os. It presents with painless vaginal bleeding. Hypertension is not a predisposing factor. High-risk factors include previous placenta previa, previous cesarean delivery, multiple gestation, advanced maternal age, multiparity, cigarette smoking, uterine fibroids, or a previous uterine surgical procedure. 

Option D: Placenta accreta is a type of morbidly adherent placenta where the placental villi are attached to the myometrium. Risk factors include prior cesarian delivery, prior uterine surgery, prior curettage, and endometrial ablation, associated placenta previa.

Option C: Placental insufficiency from hypertension can result in oligohydramnios but not polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A premature newborn is shifted to NICU with tachypnea, audible respiratory grunting, intercostal retractions, and cyanosis. An X-ray revealed ground glass opacities and air bronchograms. Which of the following cells marked in the respiratory epithelium below are involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Type II pneumocytes, which are marked as 2 in the above image, are damaged in RDS.

RDS is seen in premature infants, due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. 

The risk of developing RDS is further increased by:

  • Maternal diabetes
  • Cesarean delivery
  • Multiple births
  • Asphyxia
  • Cold stress
  • Maternal history of previously affected infants.

Clinical features of RDS include tachypnea, audible respiratory grunting, intercostal and subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and cyanosis.

A diagnosis can be made with the presence of ground-glass opacity, low lung volumes, and air bronchograms on a chest x-ray, along with blood gas findings like hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and metabolic acidosis.

Administration of antenatal glucocorticoids can increase surfactant production and reduce the risk of RDS.

The surfactant consists of phospholipid dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine, also called lecithin, surface apoproteins, and calcium ions. This phospholipid is synthesized in type II pneumocytes in the endoplasmic reticulum, following which, it is processed in the Golgi apparatus and packed in the lamellar bodies. These surface-active agents are then released into the alveoli.

The surfactant helps to reduce the alveolar surface tension and by doing so, helps prevent their collapse. It also reduces the effort required by the respiratory muscles to expand the lungs.

However, as secretion of surfactant does not begin until the sixth and seventh months of gestation, it is very likely that in a premature infant, there is little to no surfactant present. This greatly increases the tendency of the lungs to collapse, leading to respiratory distress syndrome in the newborn.

The image below shows the functions of type I and II pneumocytes in the alveoli. 

The electron microscopy image below shows the lamellar bodies in type II pneumocytes. Red arrows indicate secreted lamellar bodies, and green arrows indicate lamellar bodies in the cytoplasm

Related Pearl: Pulmonary Surfactant Composition

Constituents

Percentage

Phospholipids, mainly dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC)

70% to 80%

Proteins

10%

Neutral lipids

10%

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: Considering normal fine motor development, a 3-year-old child will be able to copy a
questions.solution:
Considering normal fine motor development, a 3-year-old child will be able to copy a circle.

Other options:

Option A: Children with normal fine motor development are able to copy a square by 4.5 years.

Option B: Children with normal fine motor development are able to copy a cross by 4 years.

Option D: Children with normal fine motor development are able to copy a triangle by 5 years.

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaints of development of pubic and axillary hair and a sudden growth spurt. On examination, she has Tanner stage 2 breast development. USG revealed a right-sided adnexal mass. The patient underwent laparotomy to remove the tumor and the biopsy from the tumor showed characteristic Call-Exner bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario history of a sudden growth spurt with the development of pubic and axillary hair with histopathological examination revealing Call-Exner bodies is suggestive of Granulosa cell tumor.

Granulosa cell tumors cell are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the Graafian follicle. 

  • In prepubertal girls, estrogen secreted from the granulosa cell tumor results in precocious puberty.
  • In women of reproductive age, increased estrogen from granulosa cell tumors leads to abnormal uterine bleeding
  • In post-menopausal women, post-menopausal bleeding is the most characteristic symptom.

The cut section is solid/cystic and yellow/orange due to its high lipid content. On microscopy, Call-Exner bodies are seen where the granulosa cells are arranged in small clusters around a central cavity.

Other options:

Option B: Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen between 15-20 years of age. There is no excess estrogen secretion and hence no development of secondary sexual characteristics. Schiller-Duval bodies are pathognomonic in histopathology. It is characterized by cystic spaces with a tuft of vascular tissue lined by flattened epithelium.

Option C: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are a type of sex-cord stromal ovarian tumors. It is most commonly seen in women of reproductive age group. These produce excess androgens and are hence known as virilizing tumors. Menstrual irregularities and signs of virilization like hirsutism and deepening of the voice are common presenting complaints. Microscopy reveals Sertoli cells and Leydig cells.

Option D: Theca cell tumors are also estrogen-secreting sex-cord stromal ovarian tumors. However, they are most commonly seen in post-menopausal women. Microscopy reveals cortical stroma with areas of granulosa cells.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with back pain, suprapubic discomfort, and a burning sensation on urination for the past three days. Since yesterday, she has developed a high fever, nausea, and vomiting. She has a past medical history of type 1 diabetes mellitus since the age of 10 years and has been on insulin. On examination, her pulse rate was 100 beats per minute, BP was 98/66 mmHg, and temperature was  103.2°F. There is focal severe pain at the right costovertebral angle. Urinalysis shows bacteria that were too numerous to count and there were 30–50 WBCs per high-power field. Urine leukocyte esterase test and Griess nitrite tests were positive. Organism isolated after urine culture is positive for indole. What is the most likely agent responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms and laboratory tests suggesting a nitrate-reducing and indole positive organism point towards the diagnosis of urinary tract infection (UTI) due to E. coli.

E. coli is a gram-negative, flagellated rod. It is the most frequent cause of acute complicated urinary tract infections. It is a lactose fermenter and hence, grows on MacConkey medium to produce pink colonies. Other biochemical features of E.coli are-

Indole Positive 
MR (Methyl Red) Positive
VP (Voges Proskauer) Negative
Citrate  Negative
Nitrate reduction Positive
Urease  Negative
H2S Negative
Gelatin hydrolysis  Negative

 

Therefore, E. coli is IMViC ++−−

The presence of leukocyte esterase in the urine suggests the presence of WBCs, indicating an infection of the urinary tract. Normal urine does not contain nitrites, therefore, its presence indicates a presence of nitrate-reducing bacteria in the urine. Additionally, the growth of organisms from aseptically collected urine samples in significant numbers makes the diagnosis of UTI. Classically, the growth of 105 CFU/ml of urine is considered significant. 

UTI may be asymptomatic or present with clinical features depending on the site of localization. Lower UTI or cystitis generally presents as fever, chills, burning micturition.

However, flank pain and renal angle tenderness with vomiting and a characteristic high spiking "picket-fence" fever suggest a diagnosis of UTI complicated with acute pyelonephritis in this diabetic patient. Fluoroquinolones such as levofloxacin and ciprofloxacin are the recommended first-line agents for treatment. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole may be used in non-resistant cases. 

Other options-

Options A, C and D are unlikely because Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella, and Enterobacter species are all indole negative. 

Image showing a positive indole test-

questions.text: A 40-year-old female librarian is brought to the emergency department. Neurologic examination reveals the following: blood pressure 160/90 mm Hg, weakness on the left side of her inferior face, no weakness in upper or lower limbs, tongue deviating to the left side on the protrusion.  There is no associated sensory loss. In which of the following loci is the lesion causing these symptoms found?
questions.solution:
The given case of acute onset weakness of the face and deviation of tongue points towards a diagnosis of stroke. It may arise due to the lesion in the genu of the internal capsule carrying the corticonuclear fibers.

  • The corticonuclear aka corticobulbar fibers originate in the motor cortex - area 4 (specifically from the pyramidal cells in the inferior precentral gyrus).
  • It then descends through the corona radiata and the genu of the internal capsule.
  • It passes through the midbrain just medial to the corticospinal fibers in the basis pedunculi
  • and ends by synapsing either directly with the lower motor neurons within the cranial nerve nuclei or indirectly through the internuncial neurons.

The majority of corticonuclear fibers cross in the median plane before supplying the cranial nerve nuclei. All cranial motor nuclei receive bilateral corticonuclear connections except, facial nucleus supplying the lower part of the face, and the hypoglossal nucleus supplying the genioglossus muscle. Hence a lesion of these fibers causes contralateral clinical manifestations.

In the given case, weakness of the face and tongue deviation to the opposite side has resulted from a lesion likely in the Genu of the Internal capsule.

Other options

Retrolentiform part of the internal capsule carries fibers mainly from optic radiation. A lesion here produces homonymous hemianopia, superior quadrantanopia, or inferior quadrantanopia.

Anterior limb of the internal capsule carries fronto-pontine fibers. A lesion here produces confusion, impaired attention, agitation, and dysarthria.

Posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part and the lesion here produces contralateral hemiparesis. The posterior part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule carries sensory fibers and lesions here may produce contralateral hemi-sensory deficits.

 

Related Pearl: Internal capsule parts and fibers

Part of Internal
capsule		 Motor
fibers/descending tracts		 Sensory fibers/
ascending tracts
Anterior limb
  • Frontopontine
 Anterior thalamic radiation
Genu
  • Corticonuclear
  • Corticospinal
 Superior thalamic
radiation
Posterior limb
  • Corticospinal
  • Corticorubral
  • Frontopontine
 Superior thalamic
radiation
Retrolentiform part
  • Parietopontine
  • Occipitopontine

 

  • Occipitotectal
  • Posterior thalamic
    radiation

 

  • Optic
    radiation
Sublentiform part
  • Temporopontine
  • Parietopontine

Related Pearl: Blood supply of internal capsule.

 
Blood supply of internal capsule.

Anterior limb 

  • Recurrent artery of Heubner
Genu 
  • Recurrent artery of Heubner
  • Charcot's artery (lenticulostriate artery or artery of cerebral hemorrrahge)
Posterior limb
  • Charcot's artery (branch of Middle cerebral artery)
  • Anterior choroidal artery ( branch of internal carotid artery)
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery
Sublentiform part
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior cerebral artery
Retrolentiform part
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with a painless inguinoscrotal swelling. Examination revealed a hard, non-tender swelling in the left hemi-scrotum. It was possible to get above the swelling. The left testis was not palpable separate from the swelling. The ultrasound scan of the left and right testes, labeled as A and B respectively, is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A painless inguinoscrotal swelling and an ultrasound showing a mass that is homogenous, hypoechoic compared to surrounding stroma, and arising from within testes (image A- left testicle) are suggestive of seminoma.

Seminoma is the most common type of Germ cell tumor. The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade. It usually presents as painless testicular enlargement. Ultrasound is mandatory in all suspected cases of testicular tumors. 

Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that is devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histology shows sheets of uniform round cells with clear cytoplasm and a large central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus. It is seen as a "fried egg appearance" as shown below.

Placental alkaline phosphate(PLAP) is the tumor marker of seminoma. A rise in hCG is observed in 30% of cases and AFP is never raised in pure seminoma.

Seminoma metastasizes mainly through para-aortic lymph nodes.

An orchidectomy through an inguinal incision is performed as a definitive treatment.

Other options:

Option B-Epididymal cyst occurs due to cystic degeneration of epididymis. They usually occur in middle age and are bilateral. The tense cysts are usually posterior to the testes and feel like clusters of tiny grapes. It is visible on USG as anechoic cysts different from the testes. Treatment involves the excision of the cyst if it is single. Partial or total resection of the epididymis is required in multilocular cysts.

The image below is an ultrasound of the scrotum showing an epididymal cyst.

Option C-Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis in the scrotum. It will be brilliantly transilluminating and testes will be separately palpable. USG will show anechoic (due to fluid) reflection. Treatment involves Jaboulay's operation, in which eversion of sac upon itself is done to prevent refilling of hydrocoele sac.

The image below shows an ultrasound of the scrotum showing an anechoic hydrocele surrounding the testicle.

Option D-Cancer of the scrotum is a rare entity, which previously occurred in chimney sweepers. It presents as a wart or ulcer on the scrotum which may involve testes as it grows. It is treated by excision of the lesion with a margin of normal tissue.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.
